questions.explanation: The given findings correspond to Treacher-Collins syndrome.Treacher-Collins syndrome/Mandibulofacial dysostosis refers to a condition resulting from thehypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible.Ocular features:•Indistinct inferior orbital margin•Coloboma of the lower eyelid• Anti-mongoloid slant of palpebral fissuresSystemic features• Macrostomia with a high-arched palate• External ear deformity• Bird-like faceThe image below shows features of Treacher-Collins syndrome.Treacher-Collins syndromeDownslantinganti-mongoloidpalpebral fissuresMicrotia,Malformed earsOMARROWColobomaof the lower lidMacrostomiaMicro/retrognathiaCleft palateCraniofacial dysostosis/Crouzon syndrome refers to the premature closure of the coronal andsagittal sutures (brachycephaly-clover-leaf skull) associated with maxillary hypoplasia. Ocularassociations include the following:• Blue sclera•Megalocornea•• Aniridia• Glaucoma• Cataract•Ectopia lentis• Optic nerve hypoplasia412The image below shows a baby with Crouzon syndrome.ILSApert syndrome is the most severe form of craniosynostosis, involving premature closure ofmultiple cranial sutures (acrocephaly), along with syndactyly of the fingers and toes.The image below shows the hands of a patient with Apert syndrome.

questions.question: 405A patient with a history of trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eyemovements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario plus the supportive CT image showing the "hanging drop sign" issuggestive of a blowout fracture of the orbital wall.Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbitthat results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure.This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial413portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor. The second most common site for orbitalblowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit.The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and bloodextravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema orhemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common.Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments andorbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called asthe "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign".Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportivemanagement with analgesics and antibiotics.Le fort fracture- Is the term used to describe different types of maxillary fractures.

questions.question: What is the most common site of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.explanation: The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit.Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbitthat results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure.This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedialportion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor.The second most common site for orbital blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit (OptionA).The fractures of the roof(Option C) are relatively rare and most often do not require anytreatment.The lateral wall(Option B) of the orbit is the most solid orbital wall and a fracture hereis usually seen in injuries with extensive facial damage.The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and bloodextravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema orhemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common.Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments andorbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called asthe "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign".Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportivemanagement with analgesics and antibiotics.The below given CT image shows hanging drop sign.414The below given X-ray image in water's view shows "hanging drop sign".

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the clinical sequelae expected in a patient withorbital blowout fracture is false?

options.A: Anesthesia of the cheek is very common.
options.B: Emphysema of eyelids is more common with medial wall fracture.
options.C: Enophthalmos develops about 10 days after the injury.406
options.D: Severe ocular damage is seen in most cases.

questions.explanation: Severe ocular damage associated with a "blowout" fracture is rare.This is because a "blowout fracture" is nature's way of protecting the globe from injury.Clinical features of blow out fracture are as follows:• Periorbital edema• Paresthesia and anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side ofthe nose, upper lip, and upper teeth)• Emphysema of the eyelids-more frequent with medial wall fractures415• Proptosis-seen initially due to orbital edema and hemorrhage.• After about 10 days, as the edema decreases, the eyeball sinks backward and somewhatinferiorly, resulting in enophthalmos and mechanical ptosis.• Double diplopia- diplopia in upward as well as downward gaze

questions.question: Two people who got in a brawl are brought to the emergency department because of severefacial injuries. In one of those patients, there is periorbital ecchymosis and anesthesia overthe cheek. Orbital blowout fracture is suspected. What X-ray finding will confirm thisdiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The X-ray finding seen in an orbital blowout fracture is hanging drop/tear-drop sign.Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which representsthe orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The mostuseful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water's view.Normalorbital floorTeardropsignThe optimal time for surgery following a blowout fracture is 10–14 days.Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture are as follows:•Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma• A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum• Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanationtension on attempted upward gaze•Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm

questions.question: All of the following are characteristic clinical findings that are associated with a history ofblunt trauma to the eye, except:
questions.explanation: Vossius ring, not Soemmering's, is seen after blunt trauma to the eyeSoemmering's ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract, also known as "secondary cataract." It isthe opacity that persists or develops after extracapsular lens extraction.416Blunt trauma to the eye produces:•⚫ Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due tothe striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.• Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract.•Commotio retinae (Berlin's edema) - It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving aconsiderable area of the posterior pole with a "cherry-red spot" at foveola.

questions.question: What is the most common site of globe rupture following trauma?
questions.explanation: The superonasal limbus is the most common site of globe rupture.This occurs due to the contrecoup effect-the lower temporal quadrant is the most exposed totrauma; hence, the effect is seen in the superonasal limbus, which lies on the opposite side.

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is the following clinical finding seen?407
questions.explanation: The image shows bilateral periorbital ecchymoses, which is called the panda sign, and it is seen inbilateral anterior cranial fossa fracture. It is also known as panda eyes/raccoon eyes.The pooling of blood surrounding the eyes is most commonly associated with fractures of theanterior cranial fossa. This finding is typically not present during the initial evaluation and isdelayed by 1 to 3 days. If bilateral, this finding is highly predictive of a basilar skull fracture.

questions.question: Heterochromia iridis may be caused by which of the following intraocular foreign bodies?
questions.explanation: Heterochromia iridis may be caused by iron deposition.Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. Insiderosis bulbi, the iris is first stained greenish and later turns reddish brown, causingheterochromia iridis.Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye.
